importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was published, providing context for the current timeline of events involving Sombr and Meg’s TikTok controversy.

keyTakeAways: Sombr, a 20-year-old singer under the stage name Shane Boose, gained popularity through viral singles like 'Back to Friends' and 'Undressed' on TikTok and social media.

Meg, a 25-year-old TikTok user, posted a scathing review of Sombr’s concert at The Anthem in Washington, DC, describing it as one of the worst experiences of her life due to an overwhelmingly young audience and immature humor.
The concert audience was heavily skewed toward younger attendees, with only a few adults present, including Meg and her boyfriend, leading to Meg’s criticism of the concert's atmosphere and content.
Sombr responded to Meg’s post by calling it 'TikTok drama,' arguing that as a young artist, he expected a younger audience and that his jokes are lighthearted and consistent with his online persona.
Sombr claimed that only five minutes of the concert involved jokes, the rest being music, and he used a 'touch grass' social media gesture to emphasize the idea of living life fully and playfully.
Meg expressed surprise at the level of backlash she received, noting that despite often posting political content, this was the most hate she has received in her online presence.
The incident reflects broader tensions in social media culture between generational differences, audience expectations, and the boundaries of humor and appropriateness in live performances.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sombr, a 20-year-old singer known for viral singles like 'Back to Friends' and 'Undressed,' faced backlash from 25-year-old TikTok user Meg after her scathing review of his concert at The Anthem in Washington, DC. Meg described the event as one of the worst concert experiences of her life, citing an overwhelmingly young audience, immature humor, and inappropriate jokes such as a '6-7 joke' and a 'Sombr dating show' segment involving audience members calling their toxic exes. Sombr responded by calling the situation 'TikTok drama,' arguing that as a young artist, he expected a younger crowd and that his humor is lighthearted and consistent with his online persona. He emphasized that only five minutes of the concert featured jokes, the rest being music, and used the 'touch grass' gesture to convey a message of living life fully. Meg expressed surprise at the level of hate she received, highlighting a broader cultural tension between generational expectations and the boundaries of humor in live performance.
title: Sombr’s TikTok drama may not be something you know about, but your kids probably do
